newsitem.title: CANADA: Northern Telecom profits beat estimates.
newsitem.headline: Northern Telecom profits beat estimates.

text.p: Telecommunications equipment maker Northern Telecom Ltd. posted a 34 percent increase in third-quarter earnings on Tuesday, beating analysts' estimates by a penny and winning their applause.
"I thought (they were) pretty terrific," analyst Charles DiSanza of Gerard Klauer Mattison said of the results.
Mississauga, Ontario-based Nortel earned $113 million, or 43 cents a share, in the third quarter, versus $81 million, or 32 cents a share, in the prior year period.
Analysts' consensus estimate was 42 cents a share.
Nortel shares climbed 85 Canadian cents to C$81.85 on the Toronto Stock Exchange and added 75 cents to $61 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Revenues in the quarter rose 23 percent to $3.05 billion from $2.49 billion in the same period in 1995.
Third-quarter order input climbed to $3.09 billion from $2.69 billion, due mainly to increases in the U.S., Caribbean, Latin American and European markets.
Nortel saw more than 50 percent growth in wireless revenues and posted a 30 percent increase in U.S. sales across all its product lines.

Chief Executive Jean Monty said in a telephone interview there was more "good growth" in order input ahead, likely in the range of 15 to 20 percent. Nortel's order input so far this year is ahead of its expectations.

Analysts said gross margins in the quarter of about 38.6 percent were a little shy of expectations. But sales were better than most expected. Gross margins are the difference between sales and the cost of sales.

Analyst DiSanza said Nortel's research and development spending would likely fall to about 12 percent of sales over time as last year's high level of investment -- around 16 percent of sales in the third quarter -- begins translating into increased revenues.
Research and development spending in the third quarter was $439 million or 14.4 percent of sales.
DiSanza said Nortel was capable of 25 percent earnings growth over the long term.
